STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
January 26, 2022
Antoinette Prabucki
Isabella County DHHS
1919 Parkland Drive
Mount Pleasant, MI 48858
RE: License #: CP370201201
Isabella County DHHS
1919 Parkland Drive
Mount Pleasant, MI 48858
Dear Ms. Prabucki:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
January 25, 2022. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It
should be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of
the MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of
this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular certificate of approval
license will be issued. If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan,
disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Melinda Gubbins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
701 S. Elmwood, Ste. 11
Traverse City, MI 49684
(231) 342-3721
enclosure
2

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12327 Special evaluation
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in the
agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
(a) Submit a special investigation record to the
department’s licensing authority within 5 working day
in the manner prescribed by the department.
One of two special investigation reports reviewed did not have a special investigation
record sent within 5 days as required.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation
(3) An agency shall complete a special evaluation within 45
calendar days after receipt of the information. If additional
time is required, then the agency shall inform the foster
parent, in writing, of the basis for the extension.
One of two special investigation reports reviewed was not completed within 45
calendar days as required and the agency didn’t inform the foster parent, in writing, of
the basis for the extension.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance will all additional MISEP requirements except for the following:
ISEP 6.16 Supervisory oversight
Supervisors shall meet as least monthly with each assigned
worker to review the status and progress of each case on
the worker’s caseload.
One of three open foster care files reviewed did not contain monthly meetings with
supervision as required.
File one: There was not a monthly meeting with supervision in September 2021.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note that there
are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements except
for the following:
4

FOM 801-03 Medical passports
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child’s
current and complete health information.
One of three open foster care files reviewed did not have medical passports as
required.
File one: No medical passports between August 2018-August 2021
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED (Previously cited under ISEP 6.49)
2/5/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 2/19/2021
FOM 722-08C Foster Care-Parent Agency Treatment Plan & Service
Agreement
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate,
including those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care worker,
supervisor, foster parent, caregiver, any youth age 14 and
older and in the case of placement agency foster care cases,
the local DHS office designee.
Three of three foster care files reviewed did not contain all of the required signatures
on the PATP.
One of one independent living files reviewed did not contain all of the required
signatures on the PATP.
FC file one: Father’s signature not obtained timely on 9/22 PATP (10/27) and 5/18
PATP (6/30); 12/6 PATP not uploaded so unable to verify signatures.
FC file two: 9/15 PATP missing foster parent signature.
FC file three: Parent’s signatures not obtained timely for 5/28 PATP; 7/27 PATP not
returned with signatures but not mailed to mom and dad until 8/31; 10/18 PATP foster
parent signature not obtained timely (12/15).
IL file one: no signature obtained for 6/17 PATP, documentation stating that virtual
agreement was made on 7/30 and then mailed and not returned.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined
in the following tables:
Case Plan Development/Reassessment
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before
the case plan due date.
5

Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
One of three foster care files reviewed did not have FTM’s completed as required.
One of one independent living files reviewed did not have FTM’s completed as
required.
FC file one: An FTM did not take place after placement change.
IL file one: An FTM did not take place prior to the completion of the 6/17 service plan.
FOM 722-08E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary
The caseworker must complete the DHS-69, Foster
Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary and upload to
MISACWIS within the timeframe required for the specified
action/change.
One of two closed foster care files reviewed did not have the DHS 69 Action Summary
as required.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas
The agency was not offered technical assistance.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
The facility did not request consultation during this review period.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care, substantiated
child abuse or substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period in response to the 2020 Interim Inspection
Report. During this period under review the agency expressed the impact that the
COVID-19 pandemic had on overall compliance. One citation was noted as a repeat
violation in the current inspection.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The assessment reported the agency’s difficulty in meeting requirements during the
review period because of challenges related to COVID-19. In addition, the
assessment noted challenges related to having new staff and a lack of effective
training in organizational management, engagement, and empathy.
6

The Chief Administrator assessment indicated that in response to the previous year’s
CAP, the agency incorporated specific trainings in the areas of non-compliance,
increased oversight and targeted case reads. The CA also reports the agency utilizes
an ACCESS database that is specific to their office. The database, along with
Infoview reports and the book of business are reviewed and discussed regularly. The
CA expressed optimism that several areas will continue to improve with the systems
that are in place.
Interviews
Interviews were conducted with two staff via phone. Staff acknowledged some
challenges related to COVID, however, they stated that they felt the agency handled it
very well and developed processes that were effective. Staff reported additional
challenges specifically related to licensing since that program is not part of the book
of business. The local office ACCESS database has been beneficial. Staff reported
they feel supported by supervision and supervision is always available when needed.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will
be issued a renewal of their regular license.
_ ______1/25/2022___________
Melinda Gubbins Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
